prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux of LINERs in band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of highly sub-Eddington AGNs in band 7. The AGNs in our sample have well-sample SEDs, except for a lack of data in the sub-mm to FIR range. Measuring the continuum flux in the sub-mm will allow us to fill this gap and test for different models of accretion flow. In particular, we will be able to assess the presence of Radiatively-Inefficient Accretion Flow, theorized in sub-Eddington AGNs where they would dominate the sub-mm luminosity of the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to measure the continuum flux so we did not any special request.

Optical spectra of LINERs obtained with increasing angular resolution typically show that the AGN contributes the most to the ionization spectrum on small scales (0.2"), while nuclear startbursts dominate at larger scales (1.5"). This has been verified with an ALMA observation of NGC 1097 in band 7, which shows a nuclear star formation ring around the AGN point source. This we requested observation with the highest angular resolution possible, in order to be able to discriminate between the AGN and star formation in the nuclear region.

We estimated the luminosity of our targets in band 7 to be Lbol/100 based on observations of similar targets at 350 GHZ with APEX and ALMA. This estimate of the sub-mm luminosity to bolometric luminosity ratio is also supported by the average of SED of LINERs (Eracleous et al. 2010). Based on observations of NGC 1052 with SMA, the sub-mm luminosity of LINERs may intrinsically vary up to a factor 2. We will include this possible variability in the error bars of our continuum flux measurements. Thus we want to minimize other sources of uncertainty. Since band 7 observations are time-inexpensive, we requested a sensitivity sufficient to reach S/N~10 in our dimmest target.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux of brightest sub-Eddington AGN in our sample in Band 10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of the brightest target in our sample down to S/N~10 in Band 10. Emission from Radiatively Inefficient Accretion would peak in the 100-1000 micrometer range, thus band 10 is best suited to assess the presence of a RIAF. Because Band 10 is constrained by weather conditions, we will first observe the brightest targets in our sample to confirm our method for flux estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to measure the continuum flux so we did not make any particular requirements for the number of spectral resolution elements per line width.

Optical and mid-IR spectra of LINERs show that nuclear star formation can contribute to the galaxy flux down to small scales. In order to isolate the AGN flux from the star formation and dust flux, we request the highest angular resolution possible.

We estimated the luminosity of our targets in Band 10 to be twice the luminosity in Band 7 based the SED of LINERs (Eracleous 2010) and models of accretion flows (Nemmen 2014). We then requested a sensitivity sufficient to reach a S/N~10 for each target to obtain small error bars in a small amount of time. Such a small measurement error is needed to balance the intrinsically large error bars due to possible variability of the source.

This is the brightest target in our sample, thus the easiest target to observe. We request to observe it despite its low elevation because a flux measurement in Band 10 will be give us valuable information to model the nature of the central engine.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux of some targets in Band 10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of the 5 brightest targets in our sample down to S/N~10 in Band 10. Emission from Radiatively Inefficient Accretion would peak in the 100-1000 micrometer range, thus band 10 is best suited to assess the presence of a RIAF. Because Band 10 is constrained by weather conditions, we will first observe the brightest targets in our sample to confirm our method for flux estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to measure the continuum flux so we did not make any special request.
We requested the highest angular resolution possible in order to disentangle the AGN flux from that of nuclear star formation and dust.
We requested a S/N~10 for our dimmest targets in order to limit measurements errors since the possible intrinsic variability of the sources will produce large error bars.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux of LINERs in band 10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of the 5 brightest targets in our sample down to S/N~10 in Band 10. Emission from Radiatively Inefficient Accretion would peak in the 100-1000 micrometer range, thus band 10 is best suited to assess the presence of a RIAF. Because Band 10 is constrained by weather conditions, we will first observe the brightest targets in our sample to confirm our method for flux estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will measure the continuum flux so we did not make any special request for the correlator set-up.
We requested the highest angular resolution possible to be able to disentangle the AGN flux from that of nuclear star formation or dust.
We requested a S/N~10 to ensure small measurements error bars since our error bars will be inflated by intrisic variability.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux in band 10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of the 4 brightest targets in our sample (besides NGC 3998) down to S/N~10 in Band 10. Emission from Radiatively Inefficient Accretion would peak in the 100-1000 micrometer range, thus band 10 is best suited to assess the presence of a RIAF. Because Band 10 is constrained by weather conditions, we will first observe the brightest targets in our sample to confirm our method for flux estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will measure the continuum flux so we did not make any special request.
We need the hughest angular resolution possible to disentangle the AGN flux from the nuclear star formation and dust flux.
We require a S/N~10 to minimize measurement errors since our error bars will already suffer because of intrinsic source variability.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum flux in Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will measure the flux continuum of the 4 brightest targets in our sample (besides NGC 3998) down to S/N~10 in Band 10. Emission from Radiatively Inefficient Accretion would peak in the 100-1000 micrometer range, thus band 10 is best suited to assess the presence of a RIAF. Because Band 10 is constrained by weather conditions, we will first observe the brightest targets in our sample to confirm our method for flux estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will measure the continuum flux so we are not requesting any special correlator set up.
We need the highest possible angular resolution to disentangle components.
We requested a S/N~10 for our targets in order to minimize measurement errors.
We will measure the continuum flux so we made no special request for the correlator set up.
We use the highest angular resolution possible to disentangle the AGN from star formation.
We need small measurements errors in order to minimize error vars when folding in variability.
This target is the brightest in our sample so it will be easily observable despite a low elevation.
We want to measure the flux continuum so we make no special request.
We request the highest angular resolution possible in order to disentangle the AGN flux from the star formation flux.
We request a S/N~10 in order to minimize our error bars.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Highly sub-Eddington AGNs can be found at the heart of 50% of nearby galaxies, categorized as LINERs. At low accretion rate, the structure of the accretion flow changes dramatically and produces powerful outflows in the form of wind and jets, which can affect the growth of the supermassive black hole by feedback. The SEDs of the AGN in LINERs provide primary constraints for accretion flow models, but lack data in the sub-mm to far-IR range, where the primary synchrotron radiation from the hot electrons in the flow emerges. We propose to observe a subset of LINERs with ALMA in order to measure the sub-mm fluxes of their AGN, build a more complete SED, and test our models for accretion flows at low accretion rate. ALMA's angular resolution will allow us to disentangle the AGN flux from dust emission and star formation in the nuclear region. The new data points in the SED of these weak AGNs will allow us to better constrain our models of the accretion flow, and test their dependence on accretion rate

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, University of the Pacific

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Geophysics and Atmospheric Sciences, Sao Paolo, University of
Dept of Astronomy & Astrophysics, Pennsylvania State University
